natural problem: Connie is starting an exercise program. On June 1, she will do 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, she will increase her number of sit-ups by four. On which date during the month of June will Connie first do more than 100 sit-ups in one day?
natural solution: On June $n$th, Connie will do $25 + 4(n-1)$ sit-ups. In this problem, we are trying to find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that \[25 + 4(n-1) > 100.\]  Simplifying the inequality yields $25+4n-4>100$, or $4n>79$.
The smallest positive integer $n$ that satisfies this simplified inequality is $n=20$; hence, Connie will do more than 100 sit-ups in one day on $\boxed{\text{June 20}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. S n = 25 + 4 * (n - 1)"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 1"
and h2 : "S n > 100"
shows  "n = 20"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Connie is starting an exercise program. On June 1, she will do 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, she will increase her number of sit-ups by four. On which date during the month of June will Connie first do more than 100 sit-ups in one day? The final Answer is \text{June 20}
 ### Proof
 On June $n$th, Connie will do $25 + 4(n-1)$ sit-ups. In this problem, we are trying to find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that \[25 + 4(n-1) > 100.\]  Simplifying the inequality yields $25+4n-4>100$, or $4n>79$.
 The smallest positive integer $n$ that satisfies this simplified inequality is $n=20$; hence, Connie will do more than 100 sit-ups in one day on $\boxed{\text{June 20}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. S n = 25 + 4 * (n - 1)"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 1"
and h2 : "S n > 100"
shows  "n = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A sequence $S(n)$ is defined by $S(n) = 25 + 4(n - 1)$ for all natural numbers $n \geq 1$. Find the smallest value of $n$ for which $S(n) > 100$. The final answer is $n = 20$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes connie_situps :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "connie_situps 1 = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. connie_situps (n + 1) = connie_situps n + 4"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n < 20 \<longrightarrow> connie_situps n \<le> 100"
shows  "connie_situps 20 > 100"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Connie is starting an exercise program. On June 1, she will do 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, she will increase her number of sit-ups by four. On which date during the month of June will Connie first do more than 100 sit-ups in one day? The final Answer is \text{June 20}
 ### Proof
 On June $n$th, Connie will do $25 + 4(n-1)$ sit-ups. In this problem, we are trying to find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that \[25 + 4(n-1) > 100.\]  Simplifying the inequality yields $25+4n-4>100$, or $4n>79$.
 The smallest positive integer $n$ that satisfies this simplified inequality is $n=20$; hence, Connie will do more than 100 sit-ups in one day on $\boxed{\text{June 20}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes connie_situps :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "connie_situps 1 = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. connie_situps (n + 1) = connie_situps n + 4"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n < 20 \<longrightarrow> connie_situps n \<le> 100"
shows  "connie_situps 20 > 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Connie does sit-ups every day. On the first day, she does 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, she does 4 more sit-ups than the previous day. After how many days will Connie do more than 100 sit-ups in a day? The final answer is 20 days.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sit_ups :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and day :: int
assumes h0 : "sit_ups 1 = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> sit_ups (n + 1) = sit_ups n + 4"
and h2 : "sit_ups day > 100"
shows  "day = 20"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Connie is starting an exercise program. On June 1, she will do 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, she will increase her number of sit-ups by four. On which date during the month of June will Connie first do more than 100 sit-ups in one day? The final Answer is \text{June 20}
 ### Proof
 On June $n$th, Connie will do $25 + 4(n-1)$ sit-ups. In this problem, we are trying to find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that \[25 + 4(n-1) > 100.\]  Simplifying the inequality yields $25+4n-4>100$, or $4n>79$.
 The smallest positive integer $n$ that satisfies this simplified inequality is $n=20$; hence, Connie will do more than 100 sit-ups in one day on $\boxed{\text{June 20}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes sit_ups :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and day :: int
assumes h0 : "sit_ups 1 = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> sit_ups (n + 1) = sit_ups n + 4"
and h2 : "sit_ups day > 100"
shows  "day = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: You start doing sit-ups as part of your daily routine. On the first day, you do 25 sit-ups. Each day, you increase the number of sit-ups by 4 more than the previous day. On which day will you do more than 100 sit-ups for the first time? The final answer is day 20.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and daily_situps :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "daily_situps 1 = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall> n > 0. daily_situps (n + 1) = daily_situps n + 4"
and h2 : "daily_situps n \<le> 100"
and h3 : "daily_situps (n + 1) > 100"
shows  "n = 19"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Connie is starting an exercise program. On June 1, she will do 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, she will increase her number of sit-ups by four. On which date during the month of June will Connie first do more than 100 sit-ups in one day? The final Answer is \text{June 20}
 ### Proof
 On June $n$th, Connie will do $25 + 4(n-1)$ sit-ups. In this problem, we are trying to find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that \[25 + 4(n-1) > 100.\]  Simplifying the inequality yields $25+4n-4>100$, or $4n>79$.
 The smallest positive integer $n$ that satisfies this simplified inequality is $n=20$; hence, Connie will do more than 100 sit-ups in one day on $\boxed{\text{June 20}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and daily_situps :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "daily_situps 1 = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall> n > 0. daily_situps (n + 1) = daily_situps n + 4"
and h2 : "daily_situps n \<le> 100"
and h3 : "daily_situps (n + 1) > 100"
shows  "n = 19"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Starting from day 1, you do 25 sit-ups and increase the number of sit-ups by 4 each day. On what day will you perform more than 100 sit-ups for the first time? The final answer is day 19.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes start_situps daily_increase target_situps day :: nat
assumes h0 : "start_situps = 25"
and h1 : "daily_increase = 4"
and h2 : "target_situps = 100"
and h3 : "\<forall>d. d > 0 \<longrightarrow> start_situps + daily_increase * (d - 1) \<le> target_situps"
and h4 : "start_situps + daily_increase * day > target_situps"
shows  "day = 20"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Connie is starting an exercise program. On June 1, she will do 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, she will increase her number of sit-ups by four. On which date during the month of June will Connie first do more than 100 sit-ups in one day? The final Answer is \text{June 20}
 ### Proof
 On June $n$th, Connie will do $25 + 4(n-1)$ sit-ups. In this problem, we are trying to find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that \[25 + 4(n-1) > 100.\]  Simplifying the inequality yields $25+4n-4>100$, or $4n>79$.
 The smallest positive integer $n$ that satisfies this simplified inequality is $n=20$; hence, Connie will do more than 100 sit-ups in one day on $\boxed{\text{June 20}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes start_situps daily_increase target_situps day :: nat
assumes h0 : "start_situps = 25"
and h1 : "daily_increase = 4"
and h2 : "target_situps = 100"
and h3 : "\<forall>d. d > 0 \<longrightarrow> start_situps + daily_increase * (d - 1) \<le> target_situps"
and h4 : "start_situps + daily_increase * day > target_situps"
shows  "day = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: You start doing 25 sit-ups per day and plan to increase the number of sit-ups by 4 each day. What is the first day on which you will do more than 100 sit-ups? The final answer is day 20.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and sit_ups :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sit_ups 1 = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> sit_ups n = sit_ups (n - 1) + 4"
shows  "sit_ups 20 > 100 \<and> (\<forall> k. k < 20 \<longrightarrow> sit_ups k \<le> 100)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Connie is starting an exercise program. On June 1, she will do 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, she will increase her number of sit-ups by four. On which date during the month of June will Connie first do more than 100 sit-ups in one day? The final Answer is \text{June 20}
 ### Proof
 On June $n$th, Connie will do $25 + 4(n-1)$ sit-ups. In this problem, we are trying to find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that \[25 + 4(n-1) > 100.\]  Simplifying the inequality yields $25+4n-4>100$, or $4n>79$.
 The smallest positive integer $n$ that satisfies this simplified inequality is $n=20$; hence, Connie will do more than 100 sit-ups in one day on $\boxed{\text{June 20}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and sit_ups :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sit_ups 1 = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> sit_ups n = sit_ups (n - 1) + 4"
shows  "sit_ups 20 > 100 \<and> (\<forall> k. k < 20 \<longrightarrow> sit_ups k \<le> 100)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: On the first day, a person does 25 sit-ups. From the second day onwards, they increase the number of sit-ups they do by 4 each day. At what day will they perform more than 100 sit-ups, but have not exceeded 100 sit-ups in any of the previous days? The final answer is the 20th day.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and sit_ups :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sit_ups 1 = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 1 \<longrightarrow> sit_ups n = sit_ups (n - 1) + 4"
shows  "sit_ups 20 > 100"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Connie is starting an exercise program. On June 1, she will do 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, she will increase her number of sit-ups by four. On which date during the month of June will Connie first do more than 100 sit-ups in one day? The final Answer is \text{June 20}
 ### Proof
 On June $n$th, Connie will do $25 + 4(n-1)$ sit-ups. In this problem, we are trying to find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that \[25 + 4(n-1) > 100.\]  Simplifying the inequality yields $25+4n-4>100$, or $4n>79$.
 The smallest positive integer $n$ that satisfies this simplified inequality is $n=20$; hence, Connie will do more than 100 sit-ups in one day on $\boxed{\text{June 20}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and sit_ups :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sit_ups 1 = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 1 \<longrightarrow> sit_ups n = sit_ups (n - 1) + 4"
shows  "sit_ups 20 > 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A person does 25 sit-ups on day 1. From day 2 onwards, the person does 4 more sit-ups than the previous day. Are there more than 100 sit-ups done on the 20th day?

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes date sit_ups :: nat
assumes h0 : "sit_ups 1 = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 1 \<longrightarrow> sit_ups n = sit_ups (n - 1) + 4"
shows  "\<exists> d. sit_ups d > 100 \<and> d \<le> 30 \<and> (\<forall> k < d. sit_ups k \<le> 100)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Connie is starting an exercise program. On June 1, she will do 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, she will increase her number of sit-ups by four. On which date during the month of June will Connie first do more than 100 sit-ups in one day? The final Answer is \text{June 20}
 ### Proof
 On June $n$th, Connie will do $25 + 4(n-1)$ sit-ups. In this problem, we are trying to find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that \[25 + 4(n-1) > 100.\]  Simplifying the inequality yields $25+4n-4>100$, or $4n>79$.
 The smallest positive integer $n$ that satisfies this simplified inequality is $n=20$; hence, Connie will do more than 100 sit-ups in one day on $\boxed{\text{June 20}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes date sit_ups :: nat
assumes h0 : "sit_ups 1 = 25"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 1 \<longrightarrow> sit_ups n = sit_ups (n - 1) + 4"
shows  "\<exists> d. sit_ups d > 100 \<and> d \<le> 30 \<and> (\<forall> k < d. sit_ups k \<le> 100)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: You start doing sit-ups as part of your daily exercise routine. On the first day, you do 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, you do 4 more sit-ups than the day before. Find the earliest day within the first 30 days when you will do more than 100 sit-ups.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. (25 + 4 * (i - 1)) \<le> 100"
and h2 : "25 + 4 * n > 100"
shows  "n = 20"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Connie is starting an exercise program. On June 1, she will do 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, she will increase her number of sit-ups by four. On which date during the month of June will Connie first do more than 100 sit-ups in one day? The final Answer is \text{June 20}
 ### Proof
 On June $n$th, Connie will do $25 + 4(n-1)$ sit-ups. In this problem, we are trying to find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that \[25 + 4(n-1) > 100.\]  Simplifying the inequality yields $25+4n-4>100$, or $4n>79$.
 The smallest positive integer $n$ that satisfies this simplified inequality is $n=20$; hence, Connie will do more than 100 sit-ups in one day on $\boxed{\text{June 20}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..n}. (25 + 4 * (i - 1)) \<le> 100"
and h2 : "25 + 4 * n > 100"
shows  "n = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A sequence of numbers starts with 25 and increases by 4 each time. What is the largest natural number $n$ such that the $n$-th term is less than or equal to 100? The final answer is 20.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes situps day :: nat
assumes h0 : "situps = (\<lambda>day. 25 + 4 * (day - 1))"
and h1 : "day \<in> {1..30}"
and h2 : "\<forall>d. d \<in> {1..(day - 1)} \<longrightarrow> h0 d \<le> 100"
shows  "h0 day > 100 \<Longrightarrow> day = 20"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Connie is starting an exercise program. On June 1, she will do 25 sit-ups. Each day after that, she will increase her number of sit-ups by four. On which date during the month of June will Connie first do more than 100 sit-ups in one day? The final Answer is \text{June 20}
 ### Proof
 On June $n$th, Connie will do $25 + 4(n-1)$ sit-ups. In this problem, we are trying to find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that \[25 + 4(n-1) > 100.\]  Simplifying the inequality yields $25+4n-4>100$, or $4n>79$.
 The smallest positive integer $n$ that satisfies this simplified inequality is $n=20$; hence, Connie will do more than 100 sit-ups in one day on $\boxed{\text{June 20}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes situps day :: nat
assumes h0 : "situps = (\<lambda>day. 25 + 4 * (day - 1))"
and h1 : "day \<in> {1..30}"
and h2 : "\<forall>d. d \<in> {1..(day - 1)} \<longrightarrow> h0 d \<le> 100"
shows  "h0 day > 100 \<Longrightarrow> day = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A person does sit-ups every day for 30 days. On the first day, they do 25 sit-ups, and each day after that, they do 4 more sit-ups than the previous day. If no more than 100 sit-ups are done in a day before a certain day, find the day when they do more than 100 sit-ups for the first time. The final answer is 20.
